awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Observations and Modeling of Acoustic Waves in the Ionosphere and Lower Thermosphere
awd_abstract_narration: This project will conduct a modeling and data analysis effort to assess the extent to which acoustic waves and high frequency gravity waves influence the thermal, chemical, and dynamical states of the upper atmosphere.  Specifically, the project will: (1) observe ionospheric perturbations using digital high-frequency Doppler sounders (TIDDBIT) from two North American locations; (2) use a numerical wave propagation model to infer the underlying atmospheric perturbations that cause the observed ionospheric variations and to characterize the energy and momentum flux into the ionosphere; and (3) use group velocity and raytracing models to examine sources of acoustic waves.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Several papers were published in the peer-reviewed literature that provide the results of our modeling and simulation of atmospheric acoustic-gravity waves, as described below.

Ducting of these waves can occur in the upper mesosphere/lower thermosphere (MLT) region. Airglow observations made from Alice Springs, Australia revealed a bore-like feature that was well described as a ducted wave by the full-wave model [Walterscheid et al., 2012]. The same model was used to interpret the long-range propagation of waves observed over Halley, Antarctica in terms of ducted waves [Snively et al., 2013]. A follow-up study [Heale et al., 2014a] suggests that a significant fraction of these observations could be explained by waves ducted in the stratosphere, with energy leaking upward to the airglow region in the MLT region, as first suggested by Yu and Hickey [2007].

We examined the effect of dissipating acoustic-gravity waves in the Martian thermosphere for a range of wave parameters and with amplitudes somewhat constrained by previously published observations [Walterscheid et al., 2013]. In general agreement with some of our much earlier research we find that dissipating acoustic waves cause heating at all altitudes in the thermosphere whereas dissipating gravity waves cause heating at higher altitudes and cooling at lower thermospheric altitudes driven by the effects of the sensible heat flux. The heating rates associated with dissipating acoustic waves are far greater than those associated with dissipating gravity waves, whilst these heating rates are greater for the faster acoustic waves (the latter being several hundred Kelvin per day). These heating rates did not account for intermittency of sources, which would reduce the net heating when averaged over a day. We also examined the effect that this heating would have on the escape flux (Jeans escape) of light gases, and found that it could be substantial (10-30 times larger than the basic flux) for the longer period acoustic waves and for a fast gravity wave considered.

We performed simulations of gravity waves propagating in the thermosphere using a binary gas version of the full-wave model [Hickey et al., 2015]. Our simulations demonstrated that viscosity and thermal conduction will affect the relative amplitudes and phases of the two fluctuating species in ways that cannot be ascertained from a model that simple includes the effects of mutual diffusion alone. This will be particularly important in future observations when interpreting multiple gas fluctuations in terms of gravity waves.

We used to full-wave model to simulate the upward propagation of gravity waves associated with the 2011 Tohoku tsunami [Yu et al., 2015]. Previous observations of traveling ionospheric disturbances (TIDs) inferred from GPS observations has shown a preponderance for propagation in the west and north-west directions. Our simulations showed that because the phase speed of the gravity waves generated depends on the tsunami speed which in turn depends on the ocean depth, the shallower waters to the west of the source lead to slower speeds of the westward propagating gravity waves. By considering wind effects, we show that these westward propagating waves reach the thermosphere and ionosphere with larger amplitudes than do the eastward propagating waves (the latter encounter regions of evanescence due to their high intrinsic phase speeds). Hence, we concluded that the observations published earlier in the literature could be explained (at least partially) by the different propagation speeds of the eastward and westward tsunami disturbance which translated into different speeds of the eastward and westward propagating gravity waves.
